Winners get an illustrated print of their ideas created by our resident illustrator, Jennifer Luxton!

For the past few years, YES! has watched reinterpretations of Rosie pop up all over, from Beyoncé to Standing Rock water protectors to women scientists. Now, in honor of #WomensHistoryMonth, we want to know how YOU reimagine a feminist icon for the 21st century! Is Rosie a queer Muslim researcher? Is she a stay-at-home dad? You decide.
link_name: What Would a Modern-Day Rosie the Riveter Look Like?

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for a special book launch event with Sarah van Gelder, author of The Revolution Where You Live: Stories From a 12,000-Mlle Journey Through a New America.

WHAT: National Book Launch & Free Speech TV Open House
WHERE: Free Speech TV - 2900 Welton St., Suite 300, Denver, CO 80205
WHEN: Thursday, Mar 9, 4:30pm 
COST: Free and open to the public; RSVP requested.
EVENT LINK:  http://bit.ly/FSTVOpenHouse

Free Refreshments + Door Prizes + Station Tours!

ABOUT THE FREE SPEECH TV OPEN HOUSE

Learn about Free Speech TV's independent public media news network and the critical role of independent press. FSTV is the national, independent news network committed to advancing progressive social change. As the alternative to television networks owned by billionaires, governments, and corporations, our network amplifies underrepresented voices and those working on the front lines of social, economic, and environmental justice. 

ABOUT THE REVOLUTION WHERE YOU LIVE BOOK:

With the election of Donald Trump, we know that local resistance and renewal are more vital than ever. The Revolution Where You Live offers an inspiring look into the grassroots movement-building and innovation that is already taking place across the country -- outside of the conventional media view.

The book traces Sarah's 12,000 mile solo road trip across the U.S. in her tiny truck camper -- through rust belt cities, Native reservations, Appalachia, and the south. Camping along the way, taking time to meet with youth, elders, teachers, artists, activists and other local leaders, Sarah's "slow journalism" reporting journey offers a surprising and hopeful window into communities on the rise.

"I love that this book documents the incredibly powerful and dynamic movements that are taking root around the country. Read it!" -- Mark Ruffalo, actor, director, and film producer

"Looking for hope? Here's where to find it. An inspiring account of the grassroots leaders throughout the United States who are confronting racism, the climate crisis, and poverty." -- Van Jones, CNN cohost, author, and activist

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

RELATED LINKS: 
Free Speech TV - http://www.freespeech.org
The Revolution Where You Live - http://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/
YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine
YES! Instagram - http://instagram.com/the_yes_life
link_name: Free Speech TV Open House - with Sarah van Gelder

status_message: Donna West and her three children had been living in the dark for months. Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corp., the monopoly energy provider for the city of Poughkeepsie claimed that West owed an outstanding balance of $12,882.26. It was a figure so shocking to West — she had been paying the utility company between $100 and $200 each month consistently over the last 16 years — that she carried around her bill in her purse: "I have to show people my bill because they don't believe me."
link_name: When Energy Bills Skyrocketed, These Neighbors Banded Together to Keep the Lights On—And Won

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for a special book launch event with Sarah van Gelder, author of The Revolution Where You Live: Stories From a 12,000-Mile Journey Through a New America.

WHAT: National Book Launch 
WHERE: Café con Leche - 2990 W Grand Blvd, Detroit, MI 48202
WHEN: Saturday, Feb 25, Noon - 2:00 PM
COST: Free and open to the public
EVENT LINK: 


ABOUT THE REVOLUTION WHERE YOU LIVE BOOK:

With the election of Donald Trump, we know that local resistance and renewal are more vital than ever. The Revolution Where You Live offers an inspiring look into the grassroots movement-building and innovation that is already taking place across the country -- outside of the conventional media view.

The book traces Sarah's 12,000 mile solo road trip across the U.S. in her tiny truck camper -- through rust belt cities, Native reservations, Appalachia, and the south. Camping along the way, taking time to meet with youth, elders, teachers, artists, activists and other local leaders, Sarah's "slow journalism" reporting journey offers a surprising and hopeful window into communities on the rise.

"I love that this book documents the incredibly powerful and dynamic movements that are taking root around the country. Read it!" -- Mark Ruffalo, actor, director, and film producer

"Looking for hope? Here's where to find it. An inspiring account of the grassroots leaders throughout the United States who are confronting racism, the climate crisis, and poverty." -- Van Jones, CNN cohost, author, and activist

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

RELATED LINKS: 
Café con Leche - http://www.atcafeconleche.com/
The Revolution Where You Live - http://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/
YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for a special book launch event with Sarah van Gelder, author of The Revolution Where You Live: Stories From a 12,000-Mile Journey Through a New America.

WHAT: National Book Launch 
WHERE: Jamaica Plain Forum, First Church JP, 6 Eliot St, Jamaica Plain, MA, 02130
WHEN: Thursday, Feb 16, 7:00pm
COST: Free and open to the public
EVENT LINK: http://jamaicaplainforum.org/event/the-revolution-where-you-live-local-power-in-the-age-of-trump/


ABOUT THE REVOLUTION WHERE YOU LIVE BOOK:

With the election of Donald Trump, we know that local resistance and renewal are more vital than ever. The Revolution Where You Live offers an inspiring look into the grassroots movement-building and innovation that is already taking place across the country -- outside of the conventional media view.

The book traces Sarah's 12,000 mile solo road trip across the U.S. in her tiny truck camper -- through rust belt cities, Native reservations, Appalachia, and the south. Camping along the way, taking time to meet with youth, elders, teachers, artists, activists and other local leaders, Sarah's "slow journalism" reporting journey offers a surprising and hopeful window into communities on the rise.

"I love that this book documents the incredibly powerful and dynamic movements that are taking root around the country. Read it!" -- Mark Ruffalo, actor, director, and film producer

"Looking for hope? Here's where to find it. An inspiring account of the grassroots leaders throughout the United States who are confronting racism, the climate crisis, and poverty." -- Van Jones, CNN cohost, author, and activist

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

RELATED LINKS: 
Jamaica Plain Forum - http://jamaicaplainforum.org
The Revolution Where You Live - http://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/
YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine
YES! Instagram - http://instagram.com/the_yes_life
link_name: The Revolution Where You Live: Local Power in the Age of Trump

BREAKING NEWS: After meeting with Vice President Pence today, the Acting Secretary of the Army Robert Speer reportedly has directed the Army Corps of Engineers to issue the easement needed to complete the Dakota Access pipeline. But the easement hasn't been granted yet.

The Standing Rock Sioux's statement: "We have to this date received no formal notice that the EIS has been suspended or withdrawn. To abandon the EIS would amount to a wholly unexplained and arbitrary change based on the President's personal views and, potentially, personal investments. Furthermore, the Army Corps lacks statutory authority to simply stop the preparation of the EIS and issue the easement."
link_name: Standing Rock Chairman Demands "Leader to Leader" Meeting With Trump

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for a special book launch event with Sarah van Gelder, author of The Revolution Where You Live: Stories From a 12,000-Mlle Journey Through a New America, in conversation with Marc Steiner, host of The Marc Steiner Show, and founder of the nonprofit Center for Emerging Media.

WHAT: National Book Launch 
WHERE: Red Emma's, 30 W. North Ave, Baltimore, MD
WHEN: Thursday, Feb 2, 7:30pm
COST: Free and open to the public
EVENT LINK: https://redemmas.org/events/821-sarah-van-gelder-presents-the-revolution-where-you-live--stories-from-a-12-000-mile-journey-through-a-new-america


ABOUT THE REVOLUTION WHERE YOU LIVE BOOK:

With the election of Donald Trump, we know that local resistance and renewal are more vital than ever. The Revolution Where You Live offers an inspiring look into the grassroots movement-building and innovation that is already taking place across the country -- outside of the conventional media view.

The book traces Sarah's 12,000 mile solo road trip across the U.S. in her tiny truck camper -- through rust belt cities, Native reservations, Appalachia, and the south. Camping along the way, taking time to meet with youth, elders, teachers, artists, activists and other local leaders, Sarah's "slow journalism" reporting journey offers a surprising and hopeful window into communities on the rise.

"I love that this book documents the incredibly powerful and dynamic movements that are taking root around the country. Read it!" -- Mark Ruffalo, actor, director, and film producer

"Looking for hope? Here's where to find it. An inspiring account of the grassroots leaders throughout the United States who are confronting racism, the climate crisis, and poverty." -- Van Jones, CNN cohost, author, and activist

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

RELATED LINKS: 
Red Emma's - http://redemmas.org/
The Revolution Where You Live - http://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/
YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine
YES! Instagram - http://instagram.com/the_yes_life
link_name: The Revolution Where You Live: Resistance, Renewal for Trump

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine
YES! Instagram - http://instagram.com/the_yes_life

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for a special book launch event at Powell's City of Books in Portland!

We're excited to kick-off the national tour of YES! cofounder and editor-at-large Sarah van Gelder's timely and inspiring new book, The Revolution Where You Live, just published by Berrett-Koehler Publishers [January 2017].

WHAT: National Book Launch 
WHERE: Powell's City of Books, 1005 W Burnside St, Portland, OR 97209
WHEN: Wednesday, January 25, 7:30pm
COST: Free and open to the public
EVENT LINK: http://www.powells.com/eventdetail?popup=true&eventID=789&rwndrnd=0.3082015027842313


ABOUT THE REVOLUTION WHERE YOU LIVE BOOK:

With the election of Donald Trump, we know that local resistance and renewal are more vital than ever. The Revolution Where You Live offers an inspiring look into the grassroots movement-building and innovation that is already taking place across the country -- outside of the conventional media view.

The book traces Sarah's 12,000 mile solo road trip across the U.S. in her tiny truck camper -- through rust belt cities, Native reservations, Appalachia, and the south. Camping along the way, taking time to meet with youth, elders, teachers, artists, activists and other local leaders, Sarah's "slow journalism" reporting journey offers a surprising and hopeful window into communities on the rise.

"I love that this book documents the incredibly powerful and dynamic movements that are taking root around the country. Read it!" -- Mark Ruffalo, actor, director, and film producer

"Looking for hope? Here's where to find it. An inspiring account of the grassroots leaders throughout the United States who are confronting racism, the climate crisis, and poverty." -- Van Jones, CNN cohost, author, and activist

"Jump into Sarah van Gelder's camper, and you'll see our country anew . . . just the book Americans need right now." -- Frances Moore Lappé, author of Diet for a Small Planet

"The Revolution Where You Live couldn't have come at a better time. If Woody Guthrie had penned a book to go along with 'This Land Is Your Land,' it might have read like this." -- David Bornstein, New York Times columnist

Sarah's national book tour and media events kick off this month. For a full schedule and additional details about the book, see: https://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/

ABOUT SARAH VAN GELDER

Sarah van Gelder is cofounder and editor at large of award-winning YES! Magazine, where she writes a bi-weekly column, also called, "The Revolution Where You Live." She explores the leading edge of change, writing and speaking internationally on topics ranging from cooperative economics to mass incarceration, from health to sustainable lifestyles, and on the role of solutions-oriented journalism in building a better society. Sarah is a regular guest on public radio and has also appeared on the PBS NewsHour program, Thom Hartmann's Big Picture, Democracy Now!, The Laura Flanders Show, and Free Speech TV. She is the editor of the books This Changes Everything: Occupy Wall Street and the 99 Percent Movement and Sustainable Happiness: Live Simply, Live Well, Make a Difference. 

ABOUT YES! MAGAZINE

YES! Magazine, a national nonprofit news organization based in Bainbridge, Washington, reframes the biggest problems of our time in terms of their solutions. Online and in print, YES! outlines a path forward with in-depth analysis, tools for citizen engagement, and stories about real people working for a better world. Project Censored calls YES! "the standard for solutions journalism." Democracy Now!'s Amy Goodman calls YES! a "vital voice of independent journalism." YES! is celebrating its 20th anniversary with the release of the Winter 2017 print edition, 50 Solutions—State by State.

RELATED LINKS: 
Powell's City of Books - http://www.powells.com
The Revolution Where You Live - http://revolutionwhereyoulive.org/
YES! Magazine - http://yesmagazine.org/
YES! Facebook Page - http://facebook.com/yesmagazine
YES! Instagram - http://instagram.com/the_yes_life
link_name: The Revolution Where You Live: Resistance, Renewal for Trump Era

status_message: YES! readers, we have a big announcement to share with you. After 18 years at the helm of our organization, our dear publisher and executive director, Fran Korten, is stepping down to retire. Those were big shoes to fill, but after an exhaustive national search, we're thrilled to announce that our new executive director will be Christine Hanna, founder and co-executive director of the Seattle Good Business Network! It's a wonderfully exciting way to cap off our 20th Anniversary year.
link_name: Introducing Our Next Executive Director

status_message:

YES! Magazine's Multimedia Editorial Intern assists the lead designer and editors with multimedia reporting and graphic production. status_message: BREAKING NEWS: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has notified the Standing Rock Sioux that, effective December 5, public access to Corps-managed lands north of the Cannonball River will be closed. This is essentially an eviction notice for thousands of people camping at Oceti Sakowin Camp. Other camps on private property and reservation property would not be affected by the order. The Army Corps is designating a "free-speech" zone south of the river.

BREAKING NEWS: The largest bank in Norway, DNB, announced that it has sold its assets in the Dakota Access pipeline. The news follows a massive consumer campaign demanding that financial institutions pull their financing for the project. DNB's banking division recently announced that it is investigating indigenous rights abuses and is reconsidering the credit line it offers Energy Transfer, which is reportedly 10 percent of the total funding.

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS: Today, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers announced that it would not be granting an easement for the Dakota Access pipeline at this time. "Further discussion and analysis are warranted in light of the history of the Great Sioux Nation's dispossessions of lands, the importance of Lake Oahe to the Tribe, our government-to-government relationship, and the statute governing easements through government property," the statement said.

"While these discussions are ongoing, construction on or under Corps land bordering Lake Oahe cannot occur because the Army has not made a final decision on whether to grant an easement."

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS: Norway's largest bank, DNB, announced that it will reconsider its participation in the financing of the North Dakota oil pipeline if concerns raised by Native American tribes against its construction are not addressed. 

"DNB looks with worry at how the situation around the pipeline in North Dakota has developed. The bank will therefore take initiative and use its position to bring about a more constructive process to find a solution to the conflict."  

"If these initiatives do not give appeasing answers and results, DNB will consider its further involvement in the financing of the project."

All banks funding the Dakota Access pipeline and its parent companies have been under intense public campaigns to get them to stop financing the pipeline construction.

#NoDapl #standingrock
link_name: How to Contact the 17 Banks Funding the Dakota Access Pipeline

Need a shopping detox? Artist Sarah Lazarovic has discovered a creative way to help us NOT buy things that we really don't need, and she's going to share it with our readers. 

Here's how it works:  Tell us about the thing you want to buy in the comments below, something you think about all the time—but you know that it won't be good for your bank account, your overstuffed house, or the planet. 

We'll pick our favorites and contact you. Sarah will paint you a picture of the item to help you get over it, and we'll publish it in our Winter Issue. Just in time for the holidays.

status_message:
"On September 3, the Dakota Access pipeline company attacked Native Americans with dogs and pepper spray as they protested against the $3.8 billion pipeline's construction. If completed, the pipeline would carry about 500,000 barrels of crude per day from North Dakota's Bakken oilfield to Illinois. The project has faced months of resistance from the Standing Rock Sioux tribe and members of nearly 100 more tribes from across the U.S. and Canada." -- via Democracy Now!

#NoDAPL #DakotaAccessPipeline #WaterIsLife

"On this day, 153 years ago, my great-great-grandmother Nape Hote Win (Mary Big Moccasin) survived the bloodiest conflict between the Sioux Nations and the U.S. Army ever on North Dakota soil. An estimated 300 to 400 of our people were killed in the Inyan Ska (Whitestone) Massacre, far more than at Wounded Knee. But very few know the story."

Last May, Portland Oregon's school board passed the most comprehensive climate justice resolution in the country.

It requires Portland public schools to ditch the nay-saying curriculum about climate change and replace it with lessons that nurture students to be changemakers for social and environmental justice.

Social justice and education leader @RethinkSchools has a "seed packet" of materials to help other schools around the country plan their own climate justice efforts. Share this with your school board today!

status_message: On April 12, 2015, #FreddieGray was arrested by the #Baltimore Police Department and died a week later from a severe spinal cord injury. In the past, injuries and killings of African Americans in police custody have received little media attention, but Gray's death pushed Baltimore to a tipping point. In what became known as the #BaltimoreUprising, thousands of activists flocked to the West Baltimore streets in outrage, and tension over the city's racial inequity and poor public housing conditions were catapulted to the forefront. View the full video: http://bit.ly/2b5WLAA #BlackLivesMatter
link_name: Watch: A Year After Freddie Gray, Baltimore Is Still Rising

status_message:
Take this quick survey to help us choose a cover for our upcoming issue on the gig economy: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/cover79

Four out of ten U.S. workers are not working traditional 9-to-5 jobs. The shift toward independent or "gig" work has alternatively been painted as an empowering development in which workers take advantage of new technologies and creative attitudes toward work and an exploitative one, in which greedy corporations shift work from full-time jobs with benefits to low-pay, low-security gigs. It's surely both. 

At the same time, some of the most exciting grassroots organizing today is taking place among the most "precarious" workers. Excluded from traditional protections and isolated by app-based technology, they're joining together in ways both old and new to define themselves as a force and push for standards that could lead to a more liberated future for all of us. 

Please help us choose a cover for this issue.

Want to help us with more surveys like this one? Join our Reader's Panel: https://store.yesmagazine.org/newsletter/signup.php
link_name: Choose the Next Cover of YES! Magazine

status_message:
Please join YES! Magazine for an informal happy hour with Nation writer John Nichols, and best-selling author Robert McChesney. 

They're in town for the west coast launch of their new book, People Get Ready: The Fight Against a Jobless Economy and a Citizenless Democracy. 

We're honored to host these heroes for a better democracy. 

Hope to see you!!

- = - = - = - = - = - = - = - 

DETAILS: 

Tuesday, March 8th, 5-7pm Happy Hour

Fadó -  801 1st Ave in Seattle's Pioneer Square. Look for us in the back room!

Free event. Happy hour food & drink prices through 7pm. 

- = - = - = - = - = - = - = - 

ABOUT THE NEW BOOK: PEOPLE GET READY

"This is the most important work either of us has done in our careers."

People Get Ready explains why the political upheaval of 2016 is just a glimpse at what is coming in the next two decades. The consequences of the technological revolution are about to hit hard: unemployment will spike as new technologies replace labor in the manufacturing, service, and professional sectors of an economy that is already struggling. The decline of work as we know it will hit at the worst moment imaginable: as capitalism fosters permanent stagnation, when the labor market is in decrepit shape, with declining wages, expanding poverty, mindless austerity, and scorching inequality. Only the dramatic democratization of our economy can address the existential challenges we now face. Yet, the US political process is so dominated by billionaires and corporate special interests, by corruption and monopoly, and a brain-dead corporate news media, that it stymies not just democracy but progress.

The great challenge of these times is to ensure that the tremendous benefits of technological progress are employed to serve the whole of humanity, rather than to enrich the wealthy few. We argue in People Get Ready that the United States needs a new economy in which revolutionary technologies are applied effectively to address environmental and social problems and used to rejuvenate and extend democratic institutions. Based on intense reporting, rich historical analysis, and deep understanding of the technological and social changes that are unfolding, we propose a bold strategy for democratizing our digital destiny—before it's too late—and unleashing the real power of the Internet, and of humanity.

- = - = - = - = - = - = - = - 

ABOUT JOHN NICHOLS
John Nichols writes about politics for The Nation magazine as its national affairs correspondent. Nichols is a contributing writer for The Progressive and In These Times and the associate editor of the Capital Times, the daily newspaper in Madison, Wisconsin. The keynote speaker at the 2004 Congress of the International Federation of Journalists in Athens, Nichols has been a featured presenter at conventions, conferences and public forums on media issues sponsored by the Federal Communications Commission, the Congressional Progressive Caucus, Consumers International, the Future of Music Coalition, the AFL-CIO, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, the Newspaper Guild [CWA] and dozens of other organizations.

ABOUT ROBERT MCCHESNEY
Robert W. McChesney is Research Professor in the Institute of Communications Research and the Graduate School of Library and Information Science at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. In 2002 he co-founded, with Dan Schiller, the Illinois Initiative on Global Information and Communication Policy. McChesney also hosts the Media Matters weekly radio program every Sunday afternoon on WILL-AM radio. He has written or edited eight books, including the award-winning Telecommunications, Mass Media, and Democracy: The Battle for the Control of U.S. Broadcasting, 1928-1935 (Oxford University Press, 1993), Corporate Media and the Threat to Democracy (Seven Stories Press, 1997), and, with Edward S. Herman, The Global Media: The New Missionaries of Corporate Capitalism (Cassell, 1997). McChesney's most recent books are multiple award-winning Rich Media, Poor Democracy: Communication Politics in Dubious Times ( New Press, 2000) and, with John Nichols, Our Media, Not Theirs: The Democratic Struggle Against Corporate Media (Seven Stories Press, 2002). 

CO-AUTHORS, CO-FOUNDERS:
With Robert W. McChesney, Nichols has co-authored the books It's the Media, Stupid! (Seven Stories), Our Media, Not Theirs (Seven Stories), Tragedy and Farce: How the American Media Sell Wars, Spin Elections, and Destroy Democracy (The New Press), The Death and Life of American Journalism (Nation Books), Uprising: How Wisconsin Renewed the Politics of Protest, from Madison to Wall Street (Nation Books), and People Get Ready: The Fight Against a Jobless Economy and a Citizenless Democracy.. McChesney and Nichols are the co-founders of Free Press, the nation's media-reform network, which organized the 2003 and 2005 National Conferences on Media Reform. 

- = - = - = - = - = - = - = - 

RELATED EVENTS:

Last year, New York City began turning schools in poor neighborhoods into community schools—combining rigorous instruction and extracurricular enrichment with a broad social support system.

Renaissance High School For The Arts has benefitted from the community school movement. Here's some of what the new funding has made possible: more on-campus social workers, so that teachers can focus on teaching; more art classes; professional art mentors to teach students mural-painting and help them prepare portfolios; apprenticeships in coding, poetry-writing, and more.
link_name: A Bold Shift to Make Public Schools Serve Poor Students

When 80-year-old Shirley Logsdon went into the hospital for a back injury, she came out with nearly $1,000 in debt that she would never be able to pay. For a year and a half, she received persistent phone calls from debt collectors. Then Logsdon received a letter from Rolling Jubilee. "You no longer owe the balance of this debt," it read. "It is gone, a gift with no strings attached."

Instances of communities caring for each other are all around. Read on for six more ways people are spreading compassion.
link_name: 7 Practical Ideas for Compassionate Communities, From Free College to Debt Relief

The baby boomer retirement wave, dubbed the "Silver Tsunami," means that over the coming decade, millions of business owners, will be trying to figure out how to retire and sustain the businesses they've built and the jobs they've created.

For business owners, selling to employees can yield a better sale price, reduce their tax liability from the sale and preserve their legacy.  The community retains jobs, profits and owners committed to staying locally rooted. It's a win-win.
link_name: 10 Reasons to Leave Your Company to Your Workers When You Retire

Humans naturally exaggerate threats. What's more, fear of unknown people—or "out-groups"—activates the selfish survival area of our brains.  

This might have been necessary for our ancestors, but in a global civilization this type of fear distorts public policy and drives people apart who should be working together.

So how can we overcome our fear?
link_name: The Bravest Response to Fear

status_message: These New York City middle-schoolers opened up about their experiences with race and racism in WNYC Radio's "Being 12" series.
link_name: Watch These 12-Year-Olds Talk About Race More Candidly Than Most Adults Do

status_message:
There are more than 7 billion people in the world, and, on any given day, most of us poop. 

It's easy to take access to safe, clean bathrooms for granted, but for many, finding a place to go isn't so simple. Unsanitary practices and lack of access result in thousands of deaths each day, place a burden on infrastructure, and ostracize our youth. 

There are fixes to these problems, but real solutions will require an open conversation.
link_name: Toilets: It's Time to Air Out the Issue

status_message:
The #GiveRefugeesRest campaign urges people to send a message-scrawled pillowcase and letter to their governor or even U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan—after, of course, taking a photo with the pillowcase and posting on social media.

This week, a local effort on Bainbridge Island, Washington, is carrying it further through plans to include Central American refugees, too.
link_name: The Brilliance of Using Pillowcases to #GiveRefugeesRest

status_message:
The defendants in the "Delta 5" case, charged with obstruction for blockading an oil train in September 2014, were found not guilty this Friday.

While the judge asked the jury not to consider the argument that the blockade was "necessary" in the fight against climate change, one juror reportedly told the defendants, "Thanks for the education."

#Delta5 #climatetrial #climateaction #climate #oiltrains

via CommonDreams.org
link_name: No Jail Time for Delta 5 in Historic Case That 'Welcomes Jurors to Climate Movement'

status_message:
Former Guantánamo Bay detainee:  "I am out, and I've moved on with my life, and they haven't. They're still stuck there."

via AJ+
link_name: AJ+

status_message:
"It's expensive, it's unnecessary, and it only serves as a recruitment brochure for our enemies." President Obama's words on the infamous Guantánamo Bay prison, and his promise to close it, garnered applause in the U.S. Capitol building during his final State of the Union address on Tuesday night. Yet, for those who've advocated for the detention center's closure for more than a decade, the pledge to shutter it inspired little confidence.

via TakePart.com
link_name: In Obama's Final Year, Another Promise to Close Guantánamo—but Then What?

status_message:
The people occupying a wildlife reserve in eastern Oregon say they're speaking for ranchers. But a closer look shows they're associated with movements most people find alienating. If we want to build any solidarity with those living in rural areas, we need to understand the difference.

#Oregonstandoff #OregonUnderAttack
link_name: What the Oregon Standoff Is Really About

status_message:
In Ecuador, the Kichwa people protested, sued the government, and forced oil companies out of their territory in the Amazon rainforest. 

But even though Kichwa women stood up to Big Oil and won, they still have to be vigilant. For Nina Gualinga, and other Ecuadorian women the filmmakers at We are the XX interviewed, the capitalist system that threatens their land is also a key element of the modern patriarchy.

#ecofeminism #indigenous #climatejustice #climate
link_name: Meet the Indigenous Eco-feminists of the Amazon

status_message:
We're open to creative pitches about the implications of the presidential race on progressive issues. But we're especially interested in local elections where candidates and initiatives tend to be more directly accountable to their communities. 

#Election2016 #independentmedia #solutionsjournalism
link_name: Help YES! Cover Politics

status_message: "In 2009, Sharon and I embarked upon a journey to test whether two people- an African American woman from South Side Chicago who is descended from enslaved people, and a white man from central Oregon who is descended from the largest slave-trading dynasty in U.S. history could come to grips with deep, traumatic, historic wounds and find healing. We had no idea where we would end up. We were just lost souls looking for direction and relief."
link_name: His Ancestors Were Slave Traders and Hers Were Slaves. What They Learned About Healing from a...

status_message:
When Lakisha David became depressed about not knowing where her people came from, she decided to track her family's roots—starting with a bill of sale for her great-great-great-grandmother.

It's hard for descendants of African slaves to trace the roots of their family, who for years were documented only as property. Today, many African Americans are finding ways to do it.
link_name: How This Black Student Used Documents and DNA to Find Her Slave Ancestors

status_message:
We are excited to announce that YES! reporting fellow, Marcus Harrison Green, will give the keynote address for the community celebration of Martin Luther King Jr. at Mount Zion Baptist Church in Seattle tomorrow.

#MLKday2016
link_name: MLK Celebration at Seattle Colleges

status_message:
"I used to believe, or wanted to believe, that racism was nothing more than the personal prejudices of the ignorant, who did not get the memo that the 21st century had arrived. I used to think our society had bigger fish to fry. That's how I learned to navigate being black in this country." — YES! reporting fellow, Marcus Harrison Green

#blacklivesmatter #MLKday2016
link_name: It Took Me Years to Believe That Black Lives Matter. Now Here's What I Need From You

status_message:
RIP Alan Rickman. We loved you in Harry Potter (and in so many other roles). You're remembered for your immense talent, generosity, humor ... and feminism.

via BUST Magazine
link_name: Alan Rickman's Underrated Feminism

status_message:
Oregon Climate is leading an unusual effort to put a price on carbon throughout the state. Either through a system of taxation or permits, polluters would have to pay for the carbon they emit. But the revenues, rather than feeding into the legislature's budget, would be divided equally and sent straight to every resident of Oregon.

#climate
link_name: Soon, Oregon Polluters May Have to Pay Residents for Changing the Climate

status_message:
Sousa-Rodriguez joined an immigration rally outside the Homeland Security office in Miami, with law enforcement watching. He had a near-perfect academic record in college, was president of the student government, and was the first person in his Brazilian family to become fluent in English. He had a lot to lose. But when someone handed him the bullhorn, there was only one thing he could think of to do.

"I am undocumented," he said. "Come and get me."
link_name: First He Came Out as Undocumented. Then As Gay. Here's What It Means For Immigration Debate.

status_message:
While the political spotlight tends to land on the differences that separate the right and left, the two sides may have more common ground than they think.

YES! editor-at-large, Sarah van Gelder, spoke with political activist, Ralph Nader, and editor of The American Conservative, Daniel McCarthy, about how both sides could benefit from putting an end to corporatism. 

#SOTU #endcorporaterule
link_name: Can the Left and Right Unite to End Corporate Rule?

status_message:
As a child of Indian immigrants, Rupa Shenoy has learned when strangers ask her where she's from, they don't want to hear "Iowa."

After years of confronting this same question again and again, she's had to make conscious decisions about how she wants to respond.
link_name: How Do You Explain Where You Came From When Your Grandparents Were Immigrants?

status_message:
Throughout Gaza Strip, painters, photographers, theater artists, musicians, and filmmakers are using their art as a form of therapy, and a tool of resistance. 

Residents say the art helps lessen the pain from wars, siege, and destruction.
link_name: Waging Life in a War Zone

status_message:
In 1972, #DavidBowie took on the identity of Ziggy Stardust, a gender-queer rock star from outer space. Throughout his life he pushed boundaries, challenged norms, and helped shape popular culture—and, in turn, our society—to be more inclusive and open-minded.

Here's how today's social change movements can be inspired by the badass spirit of Bowie.
link_name: 3 Ways to Bring David Bowie's Spirit to Your Social Change Work

status_message: In a 1983 interview with MTV, Bowie turns the tables on reporter Mark Goodman to grill him about the youth-oriented network's lack of ethnic diversity. "It's a solid enterprise, and it's got a lot going for it," Bowie starts off. "I'm just floored by the fact that there's so few black artists featured in it. Why is that?"
link_name: Watch David Bowie Grill MTV About Its Enormous Lack of Diversity in 1983

status_message:
Fueled by frustration over large class sizes, lack of basic classroom amenities, and dilapidated buildings, Detroit teachers waged a "sickout" earlier this week.

#sickout #DPSfightback

link_name: Detroit teachers' sickout shut down schools as officials scramble for recourse

status_message:
Latinos are the least likely ethnic group to vote. 

Students at Emerging Latino Leaders Fellowship are working to change that, and get more Latino youth engaged with the coming elections.

status_message:
"It is worth remembering that because of its structural nature, this is an industry that has killed for profit throughout its history. In my home state of West Virginia, which has been extracting fossil fuels longer than anywhere else in this country, coal has cost countless lives and has left the state as the least livable in the nation." — Tim DeChristopher, Climate Disobedience Center

#Delta5 #climatetrial #climatejustice #climate #bidder70
link_name: Tim DeChristopher Went to Prison for the Climate. Now He Wants Churches To Take Moral Leadership

History is being made this week in a packed Seattle-area courtroom as five activists standing trial for blocking an oil train argue that they were compelled to act because of the threat of climate change.

#Delta5 #climatetrial #climateaction #climate #oiltrains

On Wednesday, TransCanada, the Canadian fossil-fuel company behind the KeystoneXL pipeline, announced that it is suing the Obama administration under the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

Environmentalists have struggled for years to get governments to regulate fossil fuels. Here's how trade deals are making that harder than ever. 

#TPP #NAFTA #KeystoneXL #climate #tarsands

Edinburgh is rolling out a plan to cap the city's speed limit at 20mph on 80% of its roads. Scotland's #slowroads movement is aiming for better pedestrian and bicycle safety, cleaner air, and less impact on the climate. 

#urbanism #climate #greenways

North Korea is facing international condemnation after claiming to have conducted a nuclear test on Wednesday. As the United Nations ponders a new round of sanctions, some peace activists say now is the time to push for a treaty to finally end the Korean War, 63 years later. 

via Democracy Now!
link_name: As North Korea Says It's Tested H-Bomb, Is It Time to Restart Peace, Disarmament Talks?

Writer Lindy West has been harassed by hundreds of trolls online. But only one ever apologized for his remarks. Lindy began to wonder, could he explain why trolls choose to be so cruel?

via This American Life
link_name: If You Don't Have Anything Nice to Say, SAY IT IN ALL CAPS

status_message:
"Why, oh, God, why would you ever go anywhere by yourself? You could get murdered! Worse, you might be bored! And you definitely are going to have to spend an extended amount of time alone with your thoughts — a fate worse than the random serial killer you're sure to come across." 

via Vox
link_name: I went on vacation alone. Why do people think that means I'm disturbed?

status_message:
While a majority of rural women in India struggle for land ownership, Khasi women—in northeastern India's mountainous state of Meghalaya—are valued as food producers in their families and communites. 

Here, the youngest daughters inherit the land—and the ancient food heritage of their mothers.
link_name: In Photos: The Seed-Saving Farmers Who Pass Down Land to Their Daughters

status_message:
#Seattle City Council members unanimously approved a measure on Dec. 14 to allow Uber drivers to form unions. 

The measure would allow drivers for taxi, for-hire, and transportation network companies—the city council's official term for app-based ride services like #Uber and #Lyft—to negotiate anything from pay rate increases to health care benefits.

#workerrights #immigrantrights
link_name: Uber's Immigrant Drivers Look Forward to Better Pay—and Bigger Voice

With the average college graduate owing nearly $30,000 in student loans, New York approved a program that would allow the state to make federal loan payments on behalf of struggling students.

#studentdebt #debt

status_message:
In 2015, YES! Magazine and the New Economy Coalition set out to solve a problem: Why don't we have better images to tell the story of the new economy?

So we asked readers like you for poster ideas and handed them over to two of our favorite artists— Favianna Rodriguez and our own lead designer Jennifer Luxton.

#neweconomy #nextsystem #localeconomies #commonomics
link_name: What's the New Economy Look Like? Here's What Our Artists Did With Your Ideas

status_message:
Marie "Konmari" Kondo's tidying method inspired a massive, global decluttering movement in 2015.

You start by herding one category at a time onto the floor: first your clothes, next your books, then paperwork, miscellaneous, and, finally, mementos. You lift one object from the pile and hold it in your hands—Does it spark joy, you ask? Incredibly, the answer will most likely be no.
link_name: My Year of Magical Tidying

status_message:
"It took three weeks to visit all the men on the block. When they were done, they were amazed at what they had found: men who knew juggling, barbecuing, bookkeeping, hunting, haircutting, bowling, investigating crimes, writing poems, fixing cars, weightlifting, choral singing, teaching dogs tricks, mathematics, praying, and how to play trumpet, drums, and sax. They found enough talent for all the kids in the neighborhood to tap into."

#community #skillshare
link_name: The Good Life? It's Close to Home

After living in the same town for 14 years, this Idaho woman decided it was finally time to meet her neighbors. Her secret? Soup Night.

The Alzheimer's Association estimates the number of people age 65 and older with Alzheimer's disease may nearly triple, from 5.1 million today to a projected 13.8 million in 2050.

While there is no cure for dementia or #Alzheimers, studies suggest strong social ties can help ward off the disease's advance.

President Obama introduced a series of executive actions to reduce gun violence yesterday. But gun control laws don't address the current of domination, individualism, and exclusion that runs beneath mainstream culture. We assume these things are normal—but are they really?

#Obama #guncontrol #mentalhealth

Despite conflicts and crises, 2015 offered glimpses of the road to a more just, compassionate, and sustainable world. #BlackLivesMatter changed hearts, minds, and policing practices, the world set ambitious goals for #climate stabilization, and the United States began a turn away from a prison state.

YES! cofounder and editor-at-large, Sarah van Gelder, gives us six reasons to be hopeful in 2016.

Last year's protests in Ferguson and Baltimore prompted military response. But when it comes to the occupation of a federal building by armed civilian activists in Oregon, authorities have adopted a "wait-and-see" approach.

status_message:
Wealth can buy many things: education, homes, vacations. It can even buy the best doctors and diet, but it can't buy health.

In the United States, the most affluent die at a greater rate in places with higher income inequality than the poorest in places with lower income inequality. 

So what is it about #incomeinequality that hurts our #health?
link_name: Income Inequality is a Health Hazard—Even for the Rich

status_message:
In 2011, a group of dedicated neighbors in northeast #Minneapolis came together to found NorthEast Investment Cooperative (NEIC), a first-of-its-kind in the U.S. #cooperative engaged in buying and developing real estate. 

Today those buildings house a bike shop, a cooperative brewery, and a bakery.

#coops #neweconomy
link_name: These Neighbors Got Together to Buy Vacant Buildings. Now They're Renting to Bakers and Brewers

Slavery made America wealthy, and racist policies since have blocked African American wealth-building. Can we calculate the economic damage?

#reparations #BlackLivesMatter
link_name: 40 Acres and a Mule Would Be at Least $6.4 Trillion Today—What the U.S. Really Owes Black America

status_message:
People who live in this desert community say their homes can serve as a model for how society can function happily without the infrastructure and modern systems we've come to expect.

#Earthships #Sustainability
link_name: The Earthships Have Landed: Inside New Mexico's Off-Grid Community Made from Trash

status_message: Thinking about your New Year's resolutions for 2016? Here are 13 of this year's most thought-provoking and useful nonfiction books on the science of a meaningful life.
link_name: Our Favorite Books on How to Live a Happy and Meaningful Life

status_message:
In traditional cultures, #debt in a broad sense—gifts to be reciprocated, memories of help rendered, obligations not yet fulfilled—was a glue that held society together. Everybody at one time or another owed something to someone else.

Today a burgeoning #debtresistance movement draws from the realization that many of these debts are not fair. Things like sneaky balloon interest hikes on mortgages and loans deliberately made to unqualified borrowers have resulted in billions of dollars of extra costs for citizens and public institutions alike.
link_name: "Don't Owe. Won't Pay." Everything You've Been Told About Debt Is Wrong

status_message:
#Affluenza: a psychological malaise supposedly affecting wealthy young people, symptoms of which include a lack of motivation, feelings of guilt, and a sense of isolation.

"We work more, to earn more, to spend more, and the spending has reached dangerously gargantuan proportions. We're shopping ourselves to death."
link_name: Affluenza's Nothing New: The Disease That Ails America

status_message:
In the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles, Project Fatherhood helps end the cycle of absent fathers and gives men a place to discuss what it means to be dads, partners, and sons in one of the city's roughest areas.

"One out of three black men winds up incarcerated. You cannot argue with that statistic. They're not absent—they're incarcerated. They care. They want to be fathers."
link_name: Project Fatherhood: Uniting the Men of LA's Toughest Communities

status_message:
In 2004, Dee Williams sold her home and bought plans for an 84-square-foot house on wheels. It cost her $10,000 to build, a quarter of which went for photovoltaic panels that generate her electricity. Now her house is paid for, and her monthly bills total about $8.

"The more intentional you are in your choices, the more every change makes room for more changes."
link_name: Living Large in a Tiny House

status_message:
In the Taliban assassination attempt on Malala Yousafzai, Shazia Ramzan and Kainat Riaz were also shot—for no more than daring to go to school. Three years later, they're more committed to education than ever.

#HeNamedMeMalala #withMalala #NobelPrize
link_name: Standing With Malala: Meet the Teenagers Who Survived the Taliban and Kept Going to School

status_message:
Despite conflicts and crises, 2015 offered glimpses of the road to a more just, compassionate, and sustainable world. #BlackLivesMatter changed hearts, minds, and policing practices, the world set ambitious goals for #climatechange stabilization, and the United States began a turn away from a prison state.

Here's six reasons to be #hopeful in the coming year.

status_message:
In the Ecuadorian Amazon a rainforest community of 1,200 Kichwa people has successfully fended off oil companies and a government intent on exploiting their land for profit. 

The community has become a beacon of hope to other #indigenous groups and to global #climatechange activists as it mobilizes to stop a new round of oil exploration. Here, people believe that their lifestyle, deeply connected to nature, holds promise for humans to save themselves from global warming and extinction.
link_name: Deep in the Amazon, a Tiny Tribe Is Beating Big Oil

status_message:
The Damayan Migrant Workers Association is a member-led organization helping Filipino workers understand and protect their rights.

The grassroots organization, led by Filipino survivors of human trafficking and other low-wage workers, has helped dozens escape abusive conditions, recover stolen wages, and pursue T visas, which allow trafficking survivors to remain in the United States.

#Coops #Damayan #NewEconomy
link_name: These Filipina Trafficking Survivors Launched a Co-Op—And They Own Their Jobs

status_message:
Marie "Konmari" Kondo's tidying method inspired a massive, global decluttering movement in 2015. 

You start by herding one category at a time onto the floor: first your clothes, next your books, then paperwork, miscellaneous, and, finally, mementos. You lift one object from the pile and hold it in your hands—Does it spark joy, you ask? Incredibly, the answer will most likely be no.
link_name: My Year of Magical Tidying

Experts working to expand affordable housing and lift people out of homelessness reflect on the year.

#affordablehousing

via TakePart.com

status_message:
We all know that there's more to our overall well-being than treating symptoms. The good news is that scientists are discovering more ways we can keep ourselves healthy without expensive medication and complicated workout regimens. 

Here are nine simple, scientifically proven—and sometimes surprising—ways to empower yourself to make the right choices for your body and health.
link_name: 9 Simple Steps to Improve Your Health (Without Joining a Gym)

status_message: Wondering what do do with your 2015 wall calendar? Try these step by step instructions to turn your old calendar into a cool #DIY gift bag.
link_name: How to Turn Your Old Calendar Into a Gift Bag

status_message:
A lot of people are enchanted with the idea of tiny homes, but find it hard to see downsizing as a viable option: You've got too much stuff you wouldn't want to part with; or you think you couldn't fit kids in quarters less than 1,000 square feet. 

So how do you fit a full-sized family into a tiny house? These two families found that the benefits of life in 200 square feet outweigh the difficulties.
link_name: Tiny House Living: How Two Families Made It Work—Teenagers, Sleepovers, Alone Time, and All

status_message:
Growing up, the pile of gaily wrapped presents underneath the tree was proof that, in spite of the financial fears, we were safe. 

So as a new parent I tried to delight over stocking stuffers, wrapping paper, and battery-powered plastic thingamabobs. But none of it made me happy.
link_name: How Sustainability Almost Ruined Christmas

status_message: More than 3.5 million people experience homelessness in the United States each year. Thankfully, a growing number of towns and cities have found a practical solution to homelessness through the construction of tiny-house villages—and housing officials are taking notice.
link_name: Tiny Houses for the Homeless: An Affordable Solution Catches On

status_message:
Today's big food and agriculture companies work hard to protect their images. They spend a lot of time and money diverting attention away from negative science related to their products and associating themselves with groups that promote healthy food and families.

For a long time, those tactics appeared to be working; but several of this year's developments suggest that they may not work for much longer.
link_name: Was 2015 the Year Big Food Began to Lose Its Sway?

status_message:
After Judith Daluz escaped from an abusive employer and reunited with her children, she struggled to make ends meet. So she started a cleaning business with other Filipinas—where she's her own boss.

#coops #damayan #neweconomy
link_name: These Filipina Trafficking Survivors Launched a Co-Op—And They Own Their Jobs

status_message: For decades, we've been taught that economic growth and buying more stuff will make us happy—while trashing the planet. The good news is, there's a better kind of happy: It starts with meaningful work, loving relationships, and a thriving natural world.
link_name: A Brief History of Happiness: How America Lost Track of the Good Life—and Where to Find It Now

status_message: In this collection of watercolor illustrations for our #GoodHealthIssue [Winter 2016], Leela Corman Illustration And Comics shares her journey through grief, after the sudden death of her first child.
link_name: After Trauma: A Graphic Journey Through Wild Healing

status_message:
The #RadicalHomemaker offers up 11 tips on how to de-stress the holidays. 

"Any family can do it, whether you are hardcore radical homemakers like we are, a dual-income family seeking ways to de-stress the season, or simply in one of those down-on-your-luck periods."
link_name: A Radical Homemaker on How to De-Stress, Have Fun, and Stay Healthy This Christmas

status_message:
This family in West Virginia is using a food bank to help transition their community away from a coal-oriented economy and towards a #neweconomy with improved health and longer life expectancy for their neighbors. 

The McKinney's maintain a garden and five hydroponic towers for Five Loaves & Two Fishes Food Bank, Inc. in McDowell Country. The produce they grow supplements the food they give out and helps teach other people in their community how to start their own gardens and agribusinesses.
link_name: A West Virginia Family Leaves Coal for Local Food—And Helps Others Do the Same

status_message:
"As a scientist at #COP21, I hoped to see a fruitful collision of the climate scientist and climate activist. I expected strong words regarding science and broader social change, but instead found that scientists who understood the problem seemed to think we could fix it without changing the status quo."

#climate #actonclimate #climatescience
link_name: COP21: Why We Should Care What Climate Scientists Think

status_message:
"Tis the season to be jolly"—but isn't that always easier said than done? 

While the holidays can bring us many joys—family reunions, good food, thoughtful gifts—they also entail an incredible amount of stress. Those family reunions can dredge up old family conflicts, the good food often requires lots of careful preparation, and holiday shopping can be a nightmare. So how can we stay grounded and present and truly let ourselves feel the holiday spirit?
link_name: Happy Holidays? 6 Ways to Get There

status_message:
Halima and her friends had to stay home from school when they couldn't afford sanitary pads. So they launched their own businesses and pooled their money for investment.

#neweconomy #commonomics
link_name: These Girls Founded a Savings and Loan Club in Kenya's Biggest Urban Slum

status_message: "In many ways, the #BlackLivesMatter movement has set the agenda for newsrooms across the country in 2015. But with more media coverage has come more backlash against perceived slights between activists and journalists."

Each holiday season, consumers cart home their purchases and wrap gifts in 4 million tons of shopping bags and wrapping paper. And since most wrapping paper contains non-paper additives, all this waste ends up in a landfill.

Why not avoid paper gift-wrap and make your own #DIY gift bags?
link_name: How to Make Homemade Gift Bags

status_message:
"A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away …"

After years reporting on the science of mindfulness, writer Jeremy Adam Smith realized that the practice of moment-to-moment, nonjudgmental awareness is a recurring theme throughout Star Wars.

#StarWars #Parenting
link_name: What Star Wars Taught Me About Being a Mindful Parent

In the Taliban assassination attempt on Malala Yousafzai, Shazia Ramzan and Kainat Riaz were also shot—for no more than daring to go to school. Three years later, they're committed to education more than ever.

status_message:

status_message:
Here's another Salmon Is Life #ParisDiaries entry from Denise Henrikson:

"We circled amongst differing needs, desires, and agendas. Some of us went to #COP21 to support the Lummi. Some of us met with a Parisian choreographer to share visions for a grand salmon dance in the coming days. 

When we met later at a cafe, tensions ran high. I felt the palpable emotions of familiar stories: Our needs are not being met. Cathy Bellew, our fellow traveller and Lummi elder, reminded us of traditional ways to keep us in harmony. Debra D'Angelo offered an indigenous Hawaiian practice she has learned called Hoʻoponopono. We looked into each other's eyes and shared these words: 'I love you. I'm sorry. Forgive me.'

Saying and hearing these words of compassion had an extraordinary effect. Thank goodness for indigenous wisdom that hasn't been lost. It makes me wonder: What would happen if I would say those words to the Earth—and really mean it? 'I love you. I'm sorry. Forgive me.'

How might it change me? What would happen if we all did?  

(Photo by Jill MacIntyre Witt.)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
#ParisDiaries update from Denise Henrikson to kick off #COP21 week two!

Dec. 6th, 2015

"Today Salmon Is Life joined indigenous peoples from all four corners of the globe on a voyage on the Seine. #PaddleToParis was a historic moment, proclaiming the first bioregional marine sanctuary in the world.

We were invited to come to the event early to tie the salmon to the railings of the barge and add to the ambience. Since people aren't allowed to gather in public spaces, renting a private barge was a way for those working together to protect nature and #indigenous cultures to meet face-to-face. This was the first in-person meeting for many of us who have been working on this shared vision. 

We watched delegates sign a canoe paddle, affirming the proclamation. When Candido Mezua, one of the Embera chiefs, offered us the paddle to sign, we were stunned. 

We were treated to beautiful Parisian food and incredible conversation. We then traveled with attendees to their ceremony at a castle in Millemont, on the outskirts of Paris, where indigenous people from all over the world have gathered together for the past week. 

Chief Phil Lane Jr. and Mona Pollaca led a ceremony that called on each of us to acknowledge the sacrifices that indigenous people in the room and across the globe have made—and continue to make—to protect Mother Earth and future generations.  

Chief Phil shared a Coast Salish word, Nawtsamaat. It means 'One home. One heart. One prayer. United in power to protect the sacred.' "

#ProtectTheSacred #IndigenousRising #FirstNations
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
More #ParisDiaries! 

Community artist Denise Henrikson is on her way to Paris today, bringing the Salmon Is Life project: i.e, hundreds of silk-batik salmon, illuminated at night, that will swim in "schools" through the city streets. 

Why salmon? As a keystone species, these fish hold entire ecosystems together. Climate change is now threatening that. "My dream was to go and raise up the voices of those who don't have a voice," Henrikson says, "the salmon in particular."

To read more about Denise and her hopes for the #COP21 #ClimateTalks: 
http://bit.ly/1lcl2dS
link_name: 350 Washington State

status_message:
#ParisDiaries update from Yvette Arellano:

"I arrived and was extremely tired but slept some and went exploring. The air was solemn, and although there are Christmas festivities underway and decorations lining the streets of Paris, it feels far from what I'm imagining an average Noel would be.

Outside Notre Dame. Some security presence but nothing overwhelming. Watching the exhibitions being assembled for #COP21, and the preparations look amazing — from solar trees to green housing to projections of Paris in 2050. My anticipation is building. 

There are ads everywhere about the COP #climatealks. We've heard some worried comments from Parisians about how it's is not a good time for this. Use of tear gas and house arrests of some protesters have made even us uneasy. Other groups like the indigenous tribunal are doing direct nonviolent action, but of course the focus will be on radicals hoping for a productive tomorrow."

To read more about Yvette and her hopes for the #ParisTalks: 
http://bit.ly/1lcl2dS

Pictured below: Yvette Arellano with fellow T.e.j.a.s organizer Yudith Nieto, plus two volunteers.

status_message:
FULL PANEL ARCHIVED AT: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUpU_cvzmsI

This #NewEconomy panel, kicking off #NewEconomyWeek, was co-hosted by the New Economy Coalition and YES! Magazine:

http://neweconomy.net/events/online-panel-%E2%80%94-using-c-word-will-new-economy-be-capitalism-or-something-else

FEATURING:
Gar Alperovitz (Next System Project)
Sohnie Black (Fund for Democratic Communities)
John Fullerton (Capital Institute)
Julie Matthaei (Wellesley College)
Keith Harrington (YES! Magazine / Moderator)

Does building a truly just, democratic and sustainable economy mean creating an entirely new system beyond capitalism—or can we reform capitalism to operate according to those values?

This is an important strategic question that new-economy advocates must come to terms with as we attempt to build public understanding of and support for a just and sustainable new system. Indeed, as the first Democratic presidential debate of the season highlighted, "capitalism" can be a politically charged and confusing term. Thus, as with all controversial terms, how we use the "c-word" matters.

Yet, as one might expect from a diverse and growing movement, new-economy advocates have widely differing views on the term. Thus, for example, while Gar Alperovitz may write of an America Beyond Capitalism, we see his friend and colleague John Fullerton promoting a Regenerative Capitalism that nonetheless resonates with Alperovitz's vision in its particulars. Some feel the need to qualify our current system as "corporate" capitalism, while others are happy to call it capitalism, plain and simple. Yet in each case the choice of terminology is a deliberate one, indicating that the differences are not merely semantic, but reflect deeper political and cultural realities that no advocate should ignore.

NEW ECONOMY WEEK (JAN 9 -13)

This New Economy Week panel will serve as a live installment of Keith Harrington's " Checkerboard Revolution" series of articles for YES! Magazine, which explores big picture strategic issues confronting the emerging new-economy movement: 
http://www.yesmagazine.org/@@also-by?author=Keith+Harrington

To shed light on this often murky issue, an expert panel will discuss varying views of capitalism from the perspective of theory and practice. The discussion will not necessarily aim to build consensus around a particular definition of capitalism, but will attempt to help participants develop a more strategic understanding of the concepts, beliefs and values we evoke when we use the c-word.

TO RSVP / REGISTER (FREE): https://actionnetwork.org/forms/1063cad78155b08d26446d02a2aa35cfa2dca3a9?hash=5d3df372deb2079f28000c3e0b1c7a69

FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT: 

Keith Harrington's Checkerboard Series of articles - http://www.yesmagazine.org/@@also-by?author=Keith+Harrington

YES! Magazine's New Economy ongoing coverage - 
http://www.yesmagazine.org/new-economy

New Economy Week - 
http://www.neweconomyweek.org/

New Economy Coalition - 
http://neweconomy.net/
link_name: Using the "C-Word": Will the New Economy Be Capitalism, or Something Else?

status_message: Donna West and her three children had been living in the dark for months. Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corp., the monopoly energy provider for the city of Poughkeepsie claimed that West owed an outstanding balance of $12,882.26. It was a figure so shocking to West — she had been paying the utility company between $100 and $200 each month consistently over the last 16 years — that she carried around her bill in her purse: "I have to show people my bill because they don't believe me."
link_name: When Energy Bills Skyrocketed, These Neighbors Banded Together to Keep the Lights On—And Won

status_message:
So many heroes last night at the The Nation Magazine's stunning 150th Anniversary event at Town Hall Seattle. What a truly inspiring evening of political thought, readings, and hope. Thank you, Nation Magazine, for your leadership in #independentmedia, for taking a stand, and for helping to build that other world, and other America, that is possible.

And a particular YES! Magazine thank-you to these two special folks, John Nichols (journalist) and WA State Senator Pramila Jayapal, for your gracious shout outs! 

(Can we also say that former YES! staffer Jessica Lind-Diamond, did an amazing job organizing this, and other #Nation150 events across the country? Kudos!)

To another 150 years!

cc: Katrina Van Den Heuvel, Naomi Klein, Dave Zirin, Kshama Sawant, Nick Licata

"The Puppies' goal was to oppose the increasing trend of Hugo Award voters nominating women and people of color, along with anyone who used speculative fiction to explore topics like racism or gender inequality. And they wanted to make people angry, which they achieved, by nominating writers and editors who had expressed blatantly racist, sexist, and homophobic views."

YES! co-founder Sarah van Gelder is on the road trip of a lifetime, traveling around the U.S. in her camper, Caracol (Spanish for "snail"), practicing what she's calling 'slow journalism'. Given some of the challenges of our time — climate change, growing economic inequities, the harmful legacies of slavery, racism, and colonialism — Sarah's on a journey to find the creative, courageous work at the edges. What solutions are emerging from the grassroots? After 20 years of reporting on inspiring social change, where does hope lie today?  

Follow Sarah's progress on the #EdgeOfChange #roadtrip here on Facebook, and find even more stories and photos on her blog, http://www.edgeofchangeroadtrip.org, her Twitter feed (http://twitter.com/sarahvangelder), and on Instagram (http://instagram.com/sarahrvangelder).

"I'm taking a road trip with a set of questions that have been building in my mind until I can no longer ignore them. Questions about the climate crisis: Is there still time before irreversible changes kick in? Questions about racial divides: How can we finally take on a legacy that continues to traumatize people, especially people of color? And questions about the economy: Is a middle class way of life a thing of the past as wealth and power concentrates in the hands of the 1%, or might there be a better, more localized way to organize our economy? In other words, is there still hope?" — Sarah van Gelder, editor-at-large

Where do you see powerful, grassroots change? Tweet your ideas and tips for Sarah's road trip to #EdgeOfChange or leave a comment below.

status_message: Research has shown that most of us make split second assumptions about people based on superficial differences in appearance. Scientists have learned to study these unconscious biases using a test called the Implicit Assumptions Test or IAT, which measures how quickly people associate negative or positive words—like "bad" or "good"—with photos of people representing different social groups—such as African Americans or the disabled—flashed upon a screen.
